titleStmt.title: Biomineral proteomics: A tool for multiple disciplinary studies

affiliation.orgName: Ministry of Education Key Laboratory of Protein Sciences

analytic.title: Biomineral proteomics: A tool for multiple disciplinary studies

biblStruct.note: Received 18 December 2020; Received in revised form 6 February 2021; Accepted 21 February 2021

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Biomineralization Proteomics Shell matrix proteins Biominerals

abstract.p: The hard tissues of animals, such as skeletons and teeth, are constructed by a biologically controlled process called biomineralization. In invertebrate animals, biominerals are considered important for their evolutionary success. These biominerals are hieratical biocomposites with excellent mechanical properties, and their formation has intrigued researchers for decades. Although proteins account for ~5 wt% of biominerals, they are critical players in biomineralization. With the development of high-throughput analysis methods, such as proteomics, biomineral protein data are rapidly accumulating, thus necessitating a refined model for biomineralization. This review focuses on biomineral proteomics in invertebrate animals to highlight the diversity of biomineral proteins (generally 40-80 proteins), and the results indicate that biomineralization includes thermodynamic crystal growth as well as intense extracellular matrix activity and/or vesicle transport. Biominerals have multiple functions linked to biological immunity and antipathogen activity. A comparison of proteomes across species and biomineral types showed that von Willebrand factor type A and epidermal growth factor, which frequently couple with other extracellular domains, are the most common domains. Combined with species-specific repetitive low complexity domains, shell matrix proteins can be employed to predict biomineral types. Furthermore, this review discusses the applications of biomineral proteomics in diverse fields, such as tissue regeneration, developmental biology, archeology, environmental science, and material science.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Biominerals refer to complex hard materials and structures formed by organisms, such as shells, bones, and teeth, and they play crucial physiological roles, such as skeletal support, food grinding, defense, and visualization [1]. Remarkably, organisms form these hieratical composite materials via macromolecules, especially proteins, under ambient conditions, which has inspired material scientists to design excellent biomaterials. A key step towards understanding biomineral formation is to determine what proteins are involved in the process.

Efforts to identify such proteins from the 1950s to 2000s used gel separation, high-performance liquid chromatography, and molecular biology techniques. For instance, the first sequenced biomineral protein was SM50 from sea urchin (Strongylocentrotus purpuratus) spicules [2]. And then Nacrein [3], MSI60 and MSI31 from pearl oyster (Pinctada fucata) shells were subsequently obtained [4]. These methods provided significant information and the initial insights into biomineral proteins, thus revealing the molecular mechanisms of biomineralization. In recent decades, the methods of investigating such materials have expanded to omics approaches, especially proteomics, which analyzes proteins directly from biominerals, thus broadening our knowledge of biomineral proteins.

Abbreviation: n.r., not reported; ECM, extracellular matrix; SMP, shell matrix proteins; RLCD, repetitive low complexity domain; vWA, von Willebrand factor (vWF) type A; FN3, fibronectin type III; WAP, whey acidic protein; A2M, alpha-2-macroglobulin; Lam-G, Laminin_G; CBM_14, carbohydrate-binding module family (peritrophin-A domain); C1Q, complement component 1q; TSP-1, thrombospondin type 1; EGF, epidermal growth factor-like; MAM and LDL-receptor, MAM (meprin-A5-protein tyrosine phosphatase mu) and LDL (low density lipoprotein) receptor; CA, carbonic anhydrase; CCP, complement control protein; Glyco-hydro-18, glycosyl hydrolase 18 family; TIMP, tissue inhibitor of metalloproteinase; ICP-1, Intra crystalline protein-1; MSP130, a mesenchyme-specific cell surface glycoprotein of sea urchin; SM50, 50 kDa sea urchin biomineralization protein; ZP, zona pellucida.

A greater number of investigational methods offer an important opportunity to understand the molecular mechanisms of biomineralization across species and may provide answers to the following questions: What proteins are needed for biomineral formation? Are there any conserved features of proteins among different species or different biominerals? What tools are needed to efficiently analyze the proteomic data? What lessons can material scientists learn from such data? Can proteomics methods be used to address questions in various fields, such as archeology and environmental science? With the aim of summarizing the accumulating proteomic studies in biominerals during the past two decades (Fig. 1), this review provides a perspective on the evolution of biomineral proteins and discusses the potential applications of these studies in various fields. In particular, this review focuses on biominerals in invertebrate animals, which do not present the bones and teeth of vertebrate animals. Recently, some excellent reviews have addressed this topic from different perspectives [5][6][7][8][9][10][11]. Complementarily, this review covers invertebrate biomineral proteomics, which may help scientists from different disciplines better understand the field and may facilitate biomineral proteomic applications in other fields.

First, the procedure of extracting proteins from biominerals is described. Usually, proteins are extracted directly from biominerals and, in many cases, mature shells. Shells are ground and cleaned with sodium hypochlorite to remove the remaining tissues. The shell powders are decalcified with acetic acid/ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid to remove minerals and separated in a gel. Protein bands are excised, in-gel digested with trypsin and analyzed with a capillary liquid chromatography system connected to a mass spectrometer. Peptide fragments are analyzed against protein databases (all mollusk proteins/all proteins predicted from the genome/proteins translated from mineral-related tissue transcriptome) using software such as SEQUEST and MASCOT. Notably, the cleaning method affects the number of identified proteins, and incomplete cleaning may introduce cellular contaminants into the proteome. These contaminants may be removed by extensively cleaning biominerals by thorough incubation of skeleton fine powder (< 200 μm) in sodium hypochlorite [12]. However, whether intracellular contaminants, such as actin, are biomineral proteins is still debatable [13].

Due to the wide distribution of biominerals, biomineral proteomics has not been performed based on any particular order but rather with quite different purposes (e.g., to study biomineralization mechanisms, the evolution of biomineralization or environmental factor effects on biomineralization, etc.) ( Fig. 1 and Table 1). Most studies have focused on mollusk animals, while fewer studies have been performed on the Echinodermata, Brachiopod, Arthropoda, Cnidaria, and Porifera phyla. The number of proteins varies within ~5 to ~400 but mostly within 100, and many biominerals have 40-80 proteins ( Fig. 1 and Table 1), which narrows down the number of biomineral proteins for further functional studies.

div.head: Refined model for biomineralization mechanism
div.p: Commonly seen biominerals include calcium carbonate, calcium phosphate, and iron-based minerals. Classically, a "chitin-silk fibroin gel proteins-acidic macromolecules" model is proposed to explain the calcium carbonate biomineralization process [14]: (1) a matrix consisting of β-chitin is constructed, with a gel comprising silk-like protein filling the space between, (2) the first mineral phase is formed, (3) individual aragonite tablets are nucleated with the help of acidic macromolecules, and (4) the tablets grow to form the mature tissue. However, this model is built on limited knowledge of proteins in biominerals. With the use of proteomics, more proteins were discovered, and despite species differences and a lack of homologous sequences, biomineral proteins can be roughly divided into the following categories (Table 1) Table 1. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) 2) Extracellular domains: von Willebrand factor type A (vWA), vWD, fibronectin type III (FN3), CCP/SUCHI, Laminin_G, epidermal growth factor (EGF), thrombospondin, transmembrane domains, scavenger receptor domain, MAM and LDL-receptor domain, zona pellucida domain, and protocadherin; 3) Immunological domains: alpha-2-macroglobulin (A2M), EF-hand, complement component 1q (C1Q), CD109 antigen, immunoglobulin, and pentraxin; 4) Polysaccharide interaction domains: chitin binding, C-type lectin, and galactose binding; 5) Enzymes: carbon anhydrase (CA), peroxidase, chitinase, tyrosinase, copper amine oxidase, oxidoreductase, glucokinase, polyenoic fatty acid isomerase, laccase, chondroitin sulfotransferases, cysteine protease, superoxide dismutase, beta-hexosaminidase, arginine kinase, peroxiredoxin, ferroxidase, peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerase (PPCTI), and alkaline phosphatase; 6) Proteinase inhibitors: serine protease inhibitor, Kunitz-like, Kazal-like, whey acidic protein (WAP), metalloprotease, and trypsin inhibitor; 7) Others: histone, tubulin, actin, myosin, globin, ubiquitin, integrin, clathrin, ferritin, heat shock protein 70, and toxins.

Based on these findings, similar refined models for biomineralization have been proposed. For example, Liu et al proposed that in addition to controlling CaCO 3 crystallization and crystal organization, these proteins may potentially regulate the extracellular microenvironment and communicate between cells and the extracellular matrix [15]. A comparison of oyster shell matrix proteins (SMPs) against other biomineral species showed that tyrosinase, chitin-related proteins, CA, SUSHI, vWA, and chitin binding were conserved, suggesting a refined shell formation model that includes both chitin and ECM-related proteins [16]. It has also been proposed that the sea urchin spicule matrix is a relatively complex mixture of proteins that not only contains matrix-specific proteins but also 1) proteins possibly important for the formation of the continuous membrane delineating the mineralization space; 2) proteins for secretory processes that deliver proteinaceous or nonproteinaceous precursors; and 3) proteins that reflect signaling events at the cell/matrix interface [17]. Together, these proteomic data across species show strong evidence that biomineral construction is an extracellular matrix activity. Accountable choices of domains with various combinations as well as low-complexity repetitive regions are utilized.

div.head: Frequency of domains in biominerals
div.p: To analyze the frequency of domains, 17 biominerals were selected as representatives: shells from two pearl oysters (P. fucata, Pinctada margaritifera), one oyster (Crassostrea gigas), one limpet (Lottia gigantea), three mussels (Mytilus galloprovincialis, Mytilus coruscus, Perna viridis), two brachiopods (Lingula anatina, Magellania venosa), one squid (Ram's Horn squid Spirula spirula), and two snails (Lymnaea stagnalis, Euhadra quaesita); skeletons from two corals (Stylophora pistillata, Acropora millepora); and teeth from limpet (Cellana toreuma) and chiton (Cryptochiton stelleri) (Fig. 2). Based on this database, the most frequent domains are vWA and EGF, which occur in 12 out of 17 selected biominerals. Highfrequency domains also include D-rich, chitin-binding, glycosidase, peroxidase, CA, G-rich, tyrosinase, CCP/SUCHI, and laminin_G; and moderate-frequency domains include V-rich, FN3, EF-hand, ubiquitin, actin, K-rich, P-rich, Q-rich and collagen. Low-frequency domains are common, with ~80% of domains appearing less than 5 times (Fig. 2, inset). This finding strongly supports the idea that biomineralization proteins share deep conservation but possess lineage-specific changes, as proposed by several studies [18]. From an evolutionary viewpoint, cooption, domain shuffling and novel gene expansion are the fundamental mechanisms for metazoan biomineralization [18].

div.head: Domain diversity determines biominerals
div.p: A question has been raised about whether we can determine which biominerals are based on proteomics. Based on the presence of domains, the species were clustered, and closely related species clustered together, with few exceptions. Additionally, the cluster can also distinguish teeth from shells. Moreover, shells of oysters clustered more closely to snail shells and squid shells than bivalve shells. The fact that snail shells clustered together with squid shells is also interesting (Fig. 3). It is tempting to use the clustering of SMPs for the determination of phylogenetic relationships among species, especially for those that are debatable.

div.head: Proteins that have multiple domains
div.p: One interesting feature is the combination of extracellular domains in biomineralization proteins, which have been discussed in various (Fig. 4). Both domains are widely found in various biominerals from shells, coral skeletons, and teeth (Fig. 4A). More interestingly, various domains have been found to combine with the vWA domain, and the most frequent domains are the chitin-binding domain. Laminin_G, RLCD, and CCP are also commonly seen. Other combinations are glucanase and immunoglobulin (Fig. 4B). Interestingly, Lingula contains the highest number of proteins, including both EGF and collagen domains among bilaterians, and the most abundant proteins contain vWA and EGF domains [19].

Considering that Lingula diverged ~520 million years ago, EGF and vWA may be seen as ancestors for biomineralization and have been frequently used in later evolved biominerals. vWA domains (IPR002035) in extracellular eukaryotic proteins mediate adhesion via metal ion-dependent adhesion sites. EGF is a polypeptide of approximately 50 amino acids with three internal disulfide bridges. The CCP modules (also known as short consensus repeat (SCRs) or SUSHI repeats) contain approximately 60 amino acid residues. They exist in a wide variety of complement and adhesion proteins (IPR000436). The CCP proteins indicate a putative relationship between shells and the immune system. Glucanases are enzymes that break down glucan, a polysaccharide made of several glucose subunits. Immunoglobulins are glycoprotein molecules produced by plasma cells. They act as a critical part of the immune response by specifically recognizing and binding to particular antigens, such as bacteria or viruses, and aiding in their destruction. The laminin_G domain is thought to mediate the attachment, migration and organization of cells into tissues during embryonic development by interacting with other ECM components (IPR001791). This domain has approximately 180-200 residues and is found in many extracellular and receptor proteins.

div.head: SMPs may vary in terms of enrichment of certain amino acids
div.p: RLCDs can be found in almost all the biominerals. For instance, Drich proteins are found in almost all biominerals (corals [20,21], shells of pearl oyster [15,22], oyster [23], mussel [24,25], barnacle [26], limpet [18], Lingula [19] and brachiopod [27]). These domains are thought to bind calcium through interactions with the carboxylate groups of Asp. Notably, RLCDs in different biominerals are speciesspecific. For instance, in Lingula, many novel SMPs are A-rich and have low molecular weights (e.g., amino acid length ~100-200) with a three-helix bundle structure that may confer elastic properties on the Lingula shell [19]. In other shells of brachiopods, G-rich and K-rich proteins were found [27]. In contrast, in the pearl oyster [15] and mussel shell [24], V-rich proteins (Alvoline-like proteins) and G-rich proteins (Shematrin, Prisilkin-39) were structural proteins. In snail shells, the most abundant protein has G-and P-rich sequences [28]. Interestingly, L-rich proteins were found to be dominant in Ram's Horn squid [29] rather than G-rich proteins. In cold-water clams [30], T-rich proteins were found, while in scallops [31], N-rich proteins were identified. In iron-based biominerals, G-rich proteins have been identified [32]. These results suggest that different biominerals may have certain species-specific RLCDs, and these differences may be one of the factors that affect the mechanical properties of biominerals. Furthermore, the number of RLCDs might be related to certain material properties of the shells. For example, the prominent "GS" domain of Lustrin, a domain believed to confer elastomeric properties to the shell, varies significantly in length between abalone species [31].

div.head: Interesting but unknown proteins
div.p: Although structural proteins, chitin-binding proteins, and acidic proteins have been elucidated, the roles of many interesting proteins found in the proteome are still unknown. Shells can function not only as protection but also as biomaterials with other potential physiological functions. For example, shell extracts may be able to stimulate osteogenic differentiation, chondrogenic effects [33] and extracellular matrix synthesis of human skin fibroblasts [34]. Some molecules from SMPs containing ECM domains and/or immunology-related domains may be responsible for such effects. Do these SMPs only have effects on crystal formation or do they indicate other biomedical effects of shells?

In addition to the above-discussed proteins, some atypical proteins not directly related to the crystal growth process have repeatedly been found in different biominerals, including arginine kinase (in mussel shell and chiton/limpet teeth) [25,32,35], Pif (in shells of pearl oyster [15], oyster [23], mussel [25], and limpet teeth [32]), and peptidyl-prolyl isomerases (in chiton/limpet teeth/limpet shells/squid horn) [18,29,32,35]. However, we still have a limited understanding of the roles of these proteins in biomineral formation, especially considering their presence in phylogenomically distant species and even in different biominerals. Do they participate directly in crystal formation or indirectly in related processes? How are they entrapped in biominerals?

div.head: Application of biomineral proteomics in diverse fields
div.p: Biominerals are organic-inorganic biocomposites that have remarkable mechanical properties and can be stored for a quite long time, making them great research models in various fields. Proteomics of biominerals can therefore provide a unique understanding in fields such as tissue regeneration, developmental biology, archeology, environmental science, and material science (Fig. 5).

div.head: Tissue regeneration-shell regeneration
div.p: Shells can be regenerated after injury, which provides an interesting model to study tissue regeneration. Studying newly formed shells as a function of time after injury could provide insights into the shell formation process in a dynamic way. One recent study attempted to identify the SMPs of repaired shells after shell damage in pearl oysters by proteomics [36], and they found that peroxidase-like protein and β-Nacetylhexosaminidase may be important players in shell repair, which is complementary to the structural observation and analysis of gene expression at the transcriptome level. The findings may lay a foundation for further studies that focus on the proteins that are actually important in the tissue regeneration process but less abundant in the biomineral process.

div.head: Developmental biology-the larval shell proteome
div.p: While many studies have been performed on adult shell SMPs, those of larval stages are less described. For example, adult mussels are sessile, although their life cycle involves planktonic larval stages. Larval biomineralization is initiated during the trochophore stage to form the first bivalve shell, prodissoconch I and II. Compared with mature shells that possess diverse mineral polymorphisms and morphologies, larval biominerals have similar microstructures and are composed only of aragonite [37]. Whether they are made from a proteome similar to the adult shell proteome is an interesting question. Alessia et al identified SMPs from the larval shell proteome of blue mussels [37]. Specifically, a comparison with adult shells reveals that nine domains are exclusive to the larval shell proteome and that only four domains (chitin binding, vWA, FN3, Kunitz) are conserved among species and developmental stages. Similar conclusions have been made from comparing larval and adult SMPs of other species [38]. Studies of larval shell proteins could help to infer the evolution of larval types. For example, they could be used to test the hypothesis that "set-aside cells" in molluscan larvae provide the evolutionary and developmental material for constructing adult structures. In addition, with the shorter time required to identify the potential effects of in vivo manipulation experiments on shell formation genes, larval shells may be a suitable model for understanding shell formation processes [38].

div.head: Archeology-biominerals in prehistory
div.p: Shells of abalone, clams, and snails were used to decorate clothing or worn as jewelry as far back as 100,000 years ago. Learning where these shells came from may help scientists understand why prehistoric people chose certain shells and not others. However, identifying shells is difficult because they lose their original features when working in ornaments. To address these issues, Sakalauskaite et al. analyzed proteomics from seven "double-buttons", or pearl-like ornaments crafted by prehistoric people in Europe [39]. Comparing the extracted proteins to those from mollusk shells showed that the double buttons were made from freshwater Unionoida mussels. The discovery helps settle a decadelong debate in archeology about the origin of the shells used to make double buttons in prehistoric Europe. Since shells/nacre/pearls are commonly used in various scenarios in prehistoric life, it is anticipated that such approaches can be applied to address the origin of those objects, thus revealing interesting aspects of people's artistic minds before. In addition, these objects may also have implications for the seasonality, diet, and other aspects of subsistence behavior [39]. Proteomics might also be useful to even identify specific species used for these objects.

div.head: Response to environmental factors
div.p: Beyond macroevolutionary considerations, proteomics data constitute an important tool for understanding the molecular bases of calcification in stony corals and for quantifying the impact of environmental changes (such as ocean acidification, ocean warming, and pollution) on this process. For instance, under changing environmental conditions, the phenotypic plasticity of shells has been seen in many mollusk species, possibly by differential expression of SMPs. To understand how the modulation of SMPs alters biomineralization, J. Arivalagan et al compared the shell proteomes of mussels living under full marine conditions in the North Sea to those living in the low saline Baltic Sea. The modulation of proteins that compose the mussel biomineralization toolkit is observed and correlates with shell traits and fracture resistance, thus providing insights into the control of biomineralization at the molecular level in the context of changing marine conditions [40]. It is anticipated that a similar research workflow can be used to predict other stressors on biominerals. For example, microstructural and compositional alterations of shells might be good indicators for environmental pollution [41,42], and proteomics may be useful in revealing such minor alterations.

div.head: Development of bioinformatic tools
div.p: Many proteins from biominerals with no known domains appear to have low complexity in nature and show biased compositions and a high proportion of intrinsic disorder. Integrated and user-friendly bioinformatics tools are urgently required to accelerate the analysis of protein sequences from proteomics. Interestingly, one such tool/website has been developed [43]. ProminTools is a user-friendly package for the comparison of two sets of protein sequences (e.g., SMPs and the control proteome) in terms of their global properties and motif content. Using previously published SMPs of the giant limpet L. gigantea, Q-, P-and Grich motifs were found to be particularly prominent and the proteins could be clustered based on their motif content even when they shared little large-scale sequence similarity. ProminTools may be used for any pairwise comparison of sets of protein sequences. For example, protein sets associated with different parts of a biomineral or different developmental stages could also be compared, and if carefully carried out, cross-species comparisons could also be made. Therefore, this tool is useful, but a more integrated website would be needed to analyze the rapidly accumulating biomineral proteins in terms of the frequency of domains and disordered regions, thus liberating researchers from analyzing SMPs from various bioinformatic websites. Cross-species and cross-tissue biominerals protein database are also needed for the predication and annotation of unknown biomineral proteins in the future.

div.head: Implications for material scientists
div.p: Shells have inspired materials scientists to synthesize remarkable materials for decades. In particular, nacre-like materials have attracted great attention, and some success has been achieved. For example, Mao et al described a mesoscale "assembly and mineralization" approach inspired by the natural process in mollusks to fabricate bulk synthetic nacre that highly resembles both the chemical composition and the hierarchical structure of natural nacre [44]. Notably, this biomimetic approach is based on the findings of shell formation mechanisms, including SMPs, although only a small number of proteins have been used for large-scale production. Recently, smart biomaterials that have multiple functions (e.g., antibacterial, anti-corrosion, self-healing, and pH-responsive) have been developed for various uses in biomedical fields [45]. Proteomics findings may provide clues for the development of such biomaterials in the future. For example, biominerals frequently contain enzymes, such as tyrosinase, proteinase inhibitors, carbon anhydrase, peroxidase, and chitinase. The incorporation of these enzymes may provide novel biochemical properties for synthetic materials.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: Proteomes of invertebrate biominerals have been rapidly accumulating for the last two decades, thus providing important insights into the molecular evolution and mechanism of biomineralization. Importantly, complex proteins found in biominerals show that they are not just a matter of thermodynamic crystal growth but also processes that involve intense extracellular matrix and/or vesicle transport. Thus, biominerals have multiple functions linked to biological immunity and antipathogen activity. By comparing proteomes across species and types of biominerals, it was found that vWA and EGF, which frequently couple with other extracellular domains, are the most commonly used domains. Combined with species-specific repetitive low-complexity domains, SMPs can be employed to predict biomineral types. Finally, it is believed that biomineral proteomics will be beneficial for answering some interesting questions in various fields, such as tissue regeneration, developmental biology, archeology, environmental science, and material science.

div.head: Author contributions
div.p: C.L. conceived the project, analyzed the data and wrote the manuscript. R.Q.Z revised the manuscript.
